RMP Comp was used to determine the alternate distance to endpoint, the model results were 0.1 mile radius. Of the entire tanker contents, only a portion was used in the RMP Comp model due to the breakdown of regulated constituents under CAA Section 112 (r).  Public receptor information was obtained using facilitys knowledge of surrounding area.  No environmental receptors are affected by an alternate release of denaturant.  

Since the facility qualifies as a Program 3 due to the close proximity of public receptors, Process Safety Management has been completed for this facility.

GENERAL ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
Please review the first section of this Executive Summary for the general accidental release prevention program information.

TAPs maintenance department performs regular preventative maintenance inspections, as required by the manufacturers recommendations and/or State and Federal regulations. Monthly visual inspections are performed and quarterly leak detection monitoring is performed and reported per NDEE requirements.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
TAP has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including a Health and Safety Plan and Facility Response Plan. TAP has evacuation and response procedures for fires, explosions, spills, etc. outlined in the facilitys Emergency Action Plan. The Plans listed as part of this Executive Summary have been prepared in accordance with the applicable regulations, as necessary.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
TAP provides safety training to its employees and contractors on an annual basis. Any changes to improve safety will be implemented immediately upon discovery of needed changes.

operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from grain. The regulated substances stored at the facility are anhydrous ammonia and a flammable mixture  natural gasoline (denaturant).

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIOS:
Worst Case Scenarios:
Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The flammable mixture stored onsite is natural gasoline, typically referred to as denaturant. Natural gasoline is used onsite to denature ethanol prior to shipment offsite. Denaturant is stored in an aboveground steel tank. The located is located in a diked containment structure that contains an impermeable liner with gravel overlay. A worst case MSDS was used to determine RMP applicability. The worst case scenario used is the release of the entire contents of the denaturant tank, causing a vapor cloud explosion. RMP Comp was used to determine the worst case distance to endpoint; the model results were 0.7 mile radius. Of the entire tank contents, only a portion was used in the RMP Comp model due to the breakdown of regulated constituents under CAA Section 112(r). Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2020 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information (i.e. schools, hospitals, etc.) was obtained using Google Earth.  No environmental receptors are affected by a worst case release of denaturant.

Alternative Scenarios:
Flammable Mixture (Denaturant):  The alternate scenario used for the flammable mixture is the release due to a tanker truck loadout spill, causing a vapor cloud fire. The endpoint used was an over pressurization of 1 PSI, a worst case option.  Denaturant deliveries at the facility typically occur during normal business hours with a facility staff member overseeing loadout operations  therefore a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides.  The loadout area also has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment of th

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Trenton Agri Products, LLC

Trenton Agri Products, LLC (TAP) is submitting this resubmission based on updated information related to population, correction of coordinates for applicable tanks, update to dates of completion and updates based on RMP audits conducted in region 7. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES:
TAP has an ongoing commitment to the health and safety of onsite employees and the surrounding community.  This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training for the proper operation and maintenance of plant equipment and preventative maintenance programs.

TAP has emergency response policies in place that are addressed in the facilitys Health and Safety Plan; Industrial Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan; Spill Prevention, Controls, and Countermeasures Plan; Facility Response Plan; and Emergency Action Plan. Most of the listed Plans require a minimum of annual training in order to keep employees educated on emergency response procedures in place at the facility. All new employees are required to undergo training on emergency response procedures prior to initiating responsibilities onsite.

TAP participated in a Full Scale Exercise with the Southwest Planning, Exercising, and Training Region on August 21, 2010, funded in part by the U.S. DHS, Hitchcock County, and TAP.  The purpose of the exercise was to bring together the hospitals, EMS, fire, law enforcement, public sector and emergency management agencies that would have responsibility in responding to a mass casualty event.  TAP has a final After Action Report detailing the exercise onsite for review by EPA during normal business hours. Additionally, another community planning training is scheduled for June 20, 2024 with Trenton Fire and Rescue.
